meanings.def: a small piece of advice about something practical
examples: tip on/for doing something handy tips for buying a computer
tip on/for something useful tips on how to save money
(British English, informal) Here are my top tips for interview success.
The blog offered various beauty tips.
His money tips and tricks could save a typical family up to £6 000 a year.
Follow these tips to improve your communication skills.
I picked up some useful tips from my ski instructor.
Take a safety tip from me—get that light fixed!
Share your gardening tips with other readers.

meanings.def: a secret or expert piece of advice about what the result of a competition, etc. is likely to be, especially about which horse is likely to win a race
examples: a hot tip for the big race

meanings.def: secret information that somebody gives, for example to the police, to warn them about an illegal activity that is going to happen or has happened
examples: The man was arrested after an anonymous tip.

meanings.def: a small amount of extra money that you give to somebody, for example somebody who serves you in a restaurant
examples: to leave a tip
He gave the waiter a generous tip.
Someone put a dollar in the tip jar.
He left the waitress a large tip.
We get fewer tips on weeknights.
Are we supposed to leave a tip?

meanings.def: the thin, pointed end of something
examples: the tips of your fingers
the tip of your nose
the northern tip of the island
The cat was black except for a patch of white on the very tip of its tail.
He ran the tips of his fingers over the bruise.

meanings.def: a small part that fits on or over the end of something
examples: a walking stick with a rubber tip

meanings.def: a place where you can take rubbish and leave it
an untidy place
examples: Their flat is a tip!

meanings.def: if a word or name is on the tip of your tongue, you are sure that you know it but you cannot remember it
only a small part of a much larger problem
examples: This figure represents only the tip of the iceberg, since as many as 90% of cases go unreported.

idioms.idiom: on the tip of your tongue
idioms.def: if a word or name is on the tip of your tongue, you are sure that you know it but you cannot remember it
only a small part of a much larger problem
examples: This figure represents only the tip of the iceberg, since as many as 90% of cases go unreported.

meanings.def: to give somebody an extra amount of money to thank them for something they have done for you as part of their job
examples: Americans were always welcome because they tended to tip heavily.
tip somebody Did you remember to tip the waiter?
tip somebody something She tipped the porter a dollar.

meanings.def: to move so that one end or side is higher than the other; to move something into this position
examples: (+ adv./prep.) The boat tipped to one side.
The seat tips forward to allow passengers into the back.
tip something (+ adv./prep.) She tipped her head back and laughed loudly.
He tipped the wheelbarrow on its side.
His hat was tipped over his forehead.
While trying to sit down, I tipped the tray and my entire dinner went onto the rug.

meanings.def: to make something/somebody come out of a container or its/their position by holding or lifting it/them at an angle
examples: She tipped the dirty water down the drain.
The bus stopped abruptly, nearly tipping me out of my seat.

meanings.def: to touch something lightly so that it moves in a particular direction
examples: The goalkeeper just managed to tip the ball over the crossbar.

meanings.def: to leave rubbish somewhere outdoors in order to get rid of it
examples: ‘No tipping.’ (= for example, on a notice)

meanings.def: to say in advance that somebody/something will be successful
examples: be tipped for something The band is being tipped for the top.
The film is being hotly tipped for Oscar success.
be tipped as something The senator has been tipped by many as a future president.
She has been widely tipped as a future CEO.
be tipped to do something The actor is tipped to win an Oscar for his performance.

meanings.def: to cover the end or edge of something with a colour, a substance, etc.
examples: be tipped with something The wings are tipped with yellow.

meanings.def: used to say that you admire somebody very much for something they have done
it is/was raining heavily
to affect the result of something in one way rather than another
examples: In an interview, smart presentation can tip the scales in your favour.
New evidence tipped the balance against the prosecution.

meanings.def: to make your plans or intentions known
to weigh a particular amount
examples: He tipped the scales at just over 80 kilos.

meanings.def: to give somebody secret information that they can use to gain an advantage for themselves
examples: There’s no way he would have bought those shares if someone in the company hadn’t tipped him the wink.

idioms.idiom: I tip my hat to somebody
idioms.def: used to say that you admire somebody very much for something they have done
to affect the result of something in one way rather than another
examples: In an interview, smart presentation can tip the scales in your favour.
New evidence tipped the balance against the prosecution.

idioms.def: to make your plans or intentions known

examples: He tipped the scales at just over 80 kilos.

idioms.idiom: tip somebody the wink | tip the wink to somebody
idioms.def: to give somebody secret information that they can use to gain an advantage for themselves
examples: There’s no way he would have bought those shares if someone in the company hadn’t tipped him the wink.
